update.description:
First pass at using gflags for command line parsing. Supports the flags `--version`, `--help`, `-h`.

I had to do some basic restructuring - moved gz_ecs into a different filename, added some CMake plumbing to generate version information.

I'm really not a fan of the way the built-in help and version messages are generated, so I replaced them with ones that matched Gazebo 8.

For reference, here's a comparison of the original gflags output with Gazebo 8's output:

```
#!bash

$ gazebo8 -h
gazebo -- Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops. This also starts the Gazebo GUI client in a separate process.

Options:
  -v [ --version ]              Output version information.
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data.
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gazebo.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg       Load a GUI plugin.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a server plugin.
  -o [ --profile ] arg          Physics preset profile name from the options in
                                the world file.




$ ./gazebo -h
gazebo: Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options]

  Flags from /home/adam/osrf/sandbox/gazebo_experimental/main.cc:
    -h (--help, Print help message) type: bool default: false currently: true

```
update.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

pullrequest.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

content.raw: Good catch. I had been mimicking Gazebo, which uses `std::cerr` in its help function. But I agree that `std::cout` is more correct.
content.html: Good catch. I had been mimicking Gazebo, which uses std::cerr in its help function. But I agree that std::cout is more correct.

pull_request.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

pullrequest.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

pull_request.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

pullrequest.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

content.raw:
nitpick: I checked a few linux commands and they print help on stdout instead of stderr. In bash see `ls --help 1>/dev/null` versus `ls --help 2>/dev/null`. How about changing `Help()` to use `std::cout` to match?

I think those commands are following the GNU coding standards which don't apply to gazebo, but I think it's nice to be consistent with them https://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/_002d_002dhelp.html
content.html:
nitpick: I checked a few linux commands and they print help on stdout instead of stderr. In bash see ls --help 1>/dev/null versus ls --help 2>/dev/null. How about changing Help() to use std::cout to match?

I think those commands are following the GNU coding standards which don't apply to gazebo, but I think it's nice to be consistent with them https://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/_002d_002dhelp.html

content.raw:
Ah, that logic was part of Utils.cmake and CMakeLists.txt that I stripped
out while in the process of converting from the ignition CMake files. It
only is called when there is a missing dependency, which is why I wasn't
seeing it. Sorry about that, hopefully it's working now :)
content.html: Ah, that logic was part of Utils.cmake and CMakeLists.txt that I stripped out while in the process of converting from the ignition CMake files. It only is called when there is a missing dependency, which is why I wasn't seeing it. Sorry about that, hopefully it's working now :)

pull_request.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

update.description:
First pass at using gflags for command line parsing. Supports the flags `--version`, `--help`, `-h`.

I had to do some basic restructuring - moved gz_ecs into a different filename, added some CMake plumbing to generate version information.

I'm really not a fan of the way the built-in help message is generated. I'd like to replace it. The `--version` output also adds "gazebo version" before the specified version string, so we may want to override that as well.

Here's a comparison with Gazebo 8's output:

```
#!bash

$ gazebo8 -h
gazebo -- Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops. This also starts the Gazebo GUI client in a separate process.

Options:
  -v [ --version ]              Output version information.
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data.
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gazebo.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg       Load a GUI plugin.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a server plugin.
  -o [ --profile ] arg          Physics preset profile name from the options in
                                the world file.




$ ./gazebo -h
gazebo: Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options]

  Flags from /home/adam/osrf/sandbox/gazebo_experimental/main.cc:
    -h (--help, Print help message) type: bool default: false currently: true

```
update.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

pull_request.title: First pass at gflags command line argument parsing

```
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gazebo.
```

content.raw:
OK, I added gflags to a new FindDependencies.cmake, so the build error
should make more sense.

You'll need to install the gflags library, it's available via *sudo apt
install libgflags-dev*.

I am learning a lot about CMake...trial by fire :) Thanks for your patience!
content.html:
OK, I added gflags to a new FindDependencies.cmake, so the build error should make more sense.

You'll need to install the gflags library, it's available via sudo apt install libgflags-dev.

I am learning a lot about CMake...trial by fire :) Thanks for your patience!

```
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data.
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gazebo.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg       Load a GUI plugin.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a server plugin.
  -o [ --profile ] arg          Physics preset profile name from the options in
                                the world file.




$ ./gazebo -h
gazebo: Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options]

  Flags from /home/adam/osrf/sandbox/gazebo_experimental/main.cc:
    -h (--help, Print help message) type: bool default: false currently: true

```

update.description:
First pass at using gflags for command line parsing. Supports the flags `--version`, `--help`, `-h`.

I had to do some basic restructuring - moved gz_ecs into a different filename, added some CMake plumbing to generate version information.

I'm really not a fan of the way the built-in help message is generated. I'd like to replace it. The `--version` output also adds "gazebo version" before the specified version string, so we may want to override that as well.

Here's a comparison with Gazebo 8's output:

```
#!bash

$ gazebo8 -h
gazebo -- Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops. This also starts the Gazebo GUI client in a separate process.

Options:
  -v [ --version ]              Output version information.
  --verbose                     Increase the messages written to the terminal.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet|dart|simbody).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data.
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  --minimal_comms               Reduce the TCP/IP traffic output by gazebo.
  -g [ --gui-plugin ] arg       Load a GUI plugin.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a server plugin.
  -o [ --profile ] arg          Physics preset profile name from the options in
                                the world file.




$ ./gazebo -h
gazebo: Run the Gazebo server and GUI.

`gazebo` [options]

  Flags from /home/adam/osrf/sandbox/gazebo_experimental/main.cc:
    -h (--help, Print help message) type: bool default: false currently: true

```
